Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Biomanufacturing: CRISPR to increase the homogeneity and efficiency of stem cell differentiation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Chan, Christina
Proposal Number: 1547518

Stem cells are promising for the regeneration of aged, injured and diseased tissues and organs, but to realize their therapeutic potential growth of unwanted cell types should be arrested, and improvement in efficiency of converting them to a specific cell type is necessary. The proposed work will examine a genome editing approach for eliminating growth of unwanted cell lineages.

The overall goal of this project is to increase the efficiency and specificity of stem cell differentiation by reducing off-target cell types through CRISPR. CRISPR/Cas9 mediated knockout of transcription factors involved in the maturation of serotonergic, glutamatergic and GABAergic phenotypes. Clones will be DNA sequenced to confirm deletions in the regions involved in serotonin, glutamate and GABA synthesis pathways, and those lacking these genes will be treated with FI (forskolin and IBMX) to induce a higher percentage of cells to express a dopaminergic phenotype. This method will also be applied to increase the efficiency and specificity of neural stem cell differentiation. The results are anticipated to easily transfer to induced pluripotent, embryonic, and adult stem cells. From an educational standpoint, this project will provide interdisciplinary training to students with an opportunity to integrate knowledge from different fields to investigate non-traditional engineering problems. The investigators will recruit and retain female and minority engineering students into the research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes

 

Stem cells are a promising cell source for the regeneration of aged, injured and diseased tissues, however, the heterogeneity of stem cells, including embryonic (ESCs), induced pluripotent (iPSCs), mesenchymal (MSCs), and neural stem cells (NSCs), presents challenges in their differentiation into a single cell lineage while minimizing generation of unwanted cell types. Therefore, to realize the therapeutic potential of stem cells, the efficiency and homogeneity of stem cell differentiation must be improved (e.g. by restricting growth of unwanted cell types).

 

Intellectual Merit of the Proposed Work: Reducing unwanted cell lineages by genome editing several genes through multiplexing via CRISPR would greatly enhance the efficiency of stem cell differentiation to a specific cell type, decrease probability of mutagenesis and render its use safer. We were able to successfully perform knock-out (KO) of T-Box, brain 1 (Tbr1) in mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and neural stem cells (NSCs). Tbr1, a critical transcription factor (TF) for the development of a glutamatergic phenotype and its expression a marker for glutamatergic projection was targeted to knockout the post-mitotic glutamatergic differentiation potential. The Tbr1 KO in both MSCs and NSCs reduced the population of glutamernergic expressing cells, thereby reducing the heterogeneity of neuronal lineages.

 

In addition, we created RUNX2 knockout (KO) MSCs using CRISPR. RUNX2 is a master transcriptional regulator for osteogenesis and is required for differentiation of MSCs into preosteoblasts. MSCs could potentially be used in cell therapy, however, concerns over safety post-transplantation remain. Compared to pluripotent cells, MSCs do not carry the risk of teratoma formation in vivo however their trilineage potential has revealed itself to be problematic. In particular, unexpected osteogenic differentiation of MSCs transplanted into sites of myocardial infarction has been observed along with calcification of the surrounding tissue. RUNX2 is the master transcriptional regulator of osteoblast differentiation from MSCs. RUNX2 initiates a cascade of gene expression critical for the formation for mature osteocytes. We created RUNX2-KO MSCs that loss their potential to spontaneously differentiate into osteoblasts. This could eventually improve the safety of MSC transplantation for cardiac infarcts.

 

Broader Impacts of the Proposed Work: The intrinsic heterogeneity within stem cell populations or undefined extrinsic effects of the cell microenvironment can carry significant risk for stem cell therapy. In the case of MSC, osteogenesis is a potentially life-threatening risk for the treatment of myocardial infarction. Similarly, the KO of glutamergic lineage in NSCs is the first step in our proof-of-concept of reducing unwanted neuronal stem cell lineages. This first step is critical in the eventual realization of stem cell-based therapies and clinical applications of tissue engineering. Finally, we have also begun transferring our approach that we applied to MSCs and NSCs to induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs).

 

From an educational standpoint, this project provided broad exposure to students with an opportunity to integrate the knowledge base from vastly different fields and to apply engineering tools to investigate non-traditional engineering problems. This project provide partial support to several graduate students. These students were involved in mentoring undergraduate students in the laboratory. The undergraduate students provide an opportunity for the graduate students in the laboratory to gain supervisory experience along with their traditional research experience. For the undergraduate students, the goal was to encourage them to pursue careers in engineering and science by exposing them to hands-on laboratory research experience.


Last Modified: 03/30/2019
Modified by: Christina Chan
